parts:
Essentially yes—provided the word “attractor” is being used in the usual dynamical-systems sense (compact + invariant + attracting) and the flow \( \Phi^{t} \) is continuous on that set.

**Why it works**

1. *Compactness* of the attractor \( \mathcal A \) makes the space of Borel probability measures on \( \mathcal A \) weak-\(*\) compact.
2. *Invariance* (\( \Phi^{t}(\mathcal A)=\mathcal A \)) lets you push any initial probability \( \mu_{0} \) forward: \( \mu_{t}= \Phi^{t}_{\#}\mu_{0} \).
3. *Cesàro averaging*  
   \[
     \bar\mu_{T}\;=\;\frac1T\int_{0}^{T}\mu_{t}\,dt
   \]
   has limit points because the family \( \{\bar\mu_{T}\}_{T>0} \) is tight.
4. Any weak-\(*\) limit \( \mu_\* \) of \( \bar\mu_{T} \) satisfies \( \Phi^{s}_{\#}\mu_\*=\mu_\* \) for every \( s\ge0 \); hence \( \mu_\* \) is an **invariant probability measure supported on \( \mathcal A \)**.

So:

* **Existence** – guaranteed.  
* **Construction** – take a time‐average (Cesàro) of the evolved measure, or equivalently, the empirical distribution along a single long trajectory.
* **Uniqueness / regularity** – *not* guaranteed; there may be many invariant measures on the same attractor, and the push-forward \( \mu_{t} \) itself need not converge without averaging.

That is exactly the Krylov–Bogolyubov recipe applied on the attractor.
And what is this average measure tell us? Why is it useful that this is something that we can calculate?

### What the Cesàro–averaged measure \(\displaystyle \bar\mu_{T}=\frac1T\!\int_{0}^{T}\!\Phi^{t}_{\#}\mu_{0}\,dt\) gives you  

| Aspect | Why it matters |
|--------|----------------|
| **A steady statistical law** | Even when the *instantaneous* distribution \(\mu_{t}\) keeps oscillating, every limit point of \(\bar\mu_{T}\) is an **invariant probability measure** \(\mu_\*\).  All “in-the-long-run” questions—mean energy, average residence time in a region, etc.—are expectations w.r.t. \(\mu_\*\). |
| **Well-defined limits of observables** | For any bounded continuous \(g\):  \(\displaystyle\lim_{T\to\infty}\int g\,d\bar\mu_{T} =\int g\,d\mu_\*\).  So you can replace \(\tfrac1T\!\int_{0}^{T}g(\Phi^{t}x)\,dt\) by a single integral against \(\mu_\*\). |
| **Foundation for ergodic theorems** | If \(\mu_\*\) happens to be **ergodic**, Birkhoff tells you that the *trajectory* average of \(g\) converges to the same number for \(\mu_\*\)-a.e. starting point—linking individual orbits to ensemble statistics. |
| **Numerical accessibility** | Long–run Monte-Carlo is exactly “simulate the flow and accumulate histogram”; as \(T\) grows the histogram approximates \(\bar\mu_{T}\) and hence any limit invariant measure.  No need to solve the Liouville or Fokker–Planck PDE. |
| **Gateway to finer structure** | Knowing at least one invariant measure lets you ask: is it unique (mixing)? absolutely continuous (stationary density) or singular (SRB)? what are its Lyapunov exponents, fractal dimension, entropy \(h_{\mu_\*}\)? |
| **Reduces infinite-dimensional dynamics to a fixed point** | On a compact attractor the space of probability measures is itself compact; proving properties of the flow often starts by analysing its fixed points in that dual space. |

---

#### Intuition in two pictures
* **Integrable rotation** \(\mu_{t}\) never settles (it keeps sliding around the circle), but \(\bar\mu_{T}\) → the uniform measure.  You recover the correct long-time statistics even though pointwise convergence fails.
* **Chaotic attractor (e.g. Lorenz)** Here \(\mu_{t}\) *does* converge to the SRB measure, but numerically you still estimate it via a long-time histogram—which is just \(\bar\mu_{T}\).

---

### Why having *some* invariant measure is already powerful

1. **Expectations exist:** you can speak of “the average value in steady state” without ambiguity.
2. **Compactness + invariance localise analysis:** every invariant measure lives on the attractor; phase-space regions outside it become irrelevant for asymptotics.
3. **Platform for uniqueness/mixing proofs:** many results (“there is a unique SRB measure”, “observables decorrelate exponentially”) start by *first* showing at least one invariant measure exists (your Cesàro limit), *then* proving no others can survive mixing estimates.

---

### Bottom line  
Computing—or at least knowing you **could** compute—the Cesàro-averaged measure turns an orbit-by-orbit dynamical problem into a *steady* probabilistic one.  It lets you replace “what happens after a very long time?” by “evaluate an integral against \(\mu_\*\),” opening the door to both rigorous analysis and practical Monte-Carlo estimation.
So is the power actually that we can make meaningful statements about long-time behavior.

Exactly.  The whole reason we bother to manufacture an invariant **measure**—even when the instantaneous density \(\rho_t\) refuses to settle—is that it turns vague “\(t\to\infty\)” questions into precise integrals over a *fixed* probabilistic object.  With a compact forward-invariant set (or better, an attractor) in place, the Cesàro-limit measure \(\mu_\*\) lets you draw the following concrete, **long-time** conclusions:

| What you may want to know | How the invariant measure answers it |
|---------------------------|--------------------------------------|
| **Asymptotic expectations**  \(\displaystyle\lim_{T\to\infty}\frac1T\int_0^{T}g(\Phi^{t}x)\,dt\) | \(\displaystyle\int g\,d\mu_\*\).  Finite, independent of the particular subsequence, and (if \(\mu_\*\) is physical) the **same** for almost every initial point. |
| **Typical location of the system** | The support of \(\mu_\*\) pinpoints the phase-space regions that are visited with positive frequency; parts of the attractor outside the support are “rare.” |
| **Probabilities of events** (e.g. “fraction of time the trajectory spends in a box \(B\)”) | \(\mu_\*(B)\).  No need to let \(t\to\infty\) in the question—just read it off the measure. |
| **Stability to perturbations** | If small changes of the vector field leave \(\mu_\*\) close in weak-\(*\) distance (statistical stability), you know long-time statistics are robust—even if individual trajectories diverge. |
| **Thermodynamic/entropy quantities** | Metric entropy \(h_{\mu_\*}\), Lyapunov exponents, fractal dimension, etc., are invariants of \(\mu_\*\); they describe chaos, information production, and geometry of long-term motion. |
| **Numerical estimation** | Long runs of a single trajectory, or Monte-Carlo sampling of many, converge to \(\mu_\*\) in the Cesàro sense, so empirical histograms approximate the same steady statistics you would compute analytically. |

#### Minimal take-away

* **Existence of \(\mu_\*\)** (via time-averaged measures on any compact invariant set) already guarantees **some** probabilistic description of the future.
* **Additional dynamical structure** (e.g., uniqueness, physicality, mixing) upgrades those statements from “there exists a steady law” to “that law is unique, attracts all reasonable initial data, and possibly does so at a quantifiable rate.”

So the “power” is precisely this bridge: you move from chasing the detailed geometry of every trajectory to manipulating a single measure that faithfully encodes everything you can meaningfully say about the system **in the long run**.
And to be clear, this is exactly the same as expectations over the initial distribution.

thoughts.content: It seems like the user is asking whether taking the expectation over the limiting invariant measure is the same as taking it over the initial distribution. After discussing concepts like Cesàro averages, invariant measures, and long-time averages, I realize the answer isn't straightforward. For a system with flow Φ^t and initial measure μ0, the expectation from an invariant measure doesn't always match the initial expectation. This only happens when μ0 is already invariant or in certain other specific conditions. So, the answer is: not in general.

parts:
Not in general.

---

### Where the two expectations differ

| stage | what is being integrated | notation | value |
|-------|-------------------------|----------|-------|
| **Initial expectation** | observable \(g\) against the **starting** distribution | \(\displaystyle\int g\,d\mu_0\) | depends only on \(\mu_0\) |
| **Long-time (Cesàro) expectation** | time-average of \(g\) along the flow, or \(g\) against the **Cesàro-limit** measure | \(\displaystyle\lim_{T\to\infty}\frac1T\int_0^{T}g\!\circ\!\Phi^{t}\,d\mu_0=\int g\,d\mu_\*\) | depends on the **invariant** measure(s) selected by the dynamics |

They coincide **only** in special cases:

* if \(\mu_0\) is already an invariant measure,  
* or if \(g\) happens to be constant,  
* or, more generally, when the system is uniquely ergodic so that every initial distribution is driven toward the same \(\mu_\*\).

---

### Why they usually differ  
1. **Transport:** the flow rearranges probability mass; dissipative systems squeeze it onto an attractor, conservative systems shear it around.  
2. **Averaging:** Cesàro averaging smooths the forward images of \(\mu_0\). Even for a volume-preserving map (e.g. an irrational circle rotation) the push-forwards never settle, but their time-average converges to the uniform measure—quite different from the Dirac you might start with.  
3. **Multiple invariant measures:** if the attractor supports several invariant measures, the limit you obtain can depend on \(\mu_0\) (which basin you start in) yet still differ from \(\mu_0\) itself.

---

### A concrete illustration  
*Take the 1-D map \(x\mapsto x+\alpha \bmod 1\) with irrational \(\alpha\).*  

* Initial distribution \(\mu_0=\delta_{0}\):  
  \(\int g\,d\mu_0=g(0)\).

* Cesàro average:  
  \(\displaystyle \bar\mu_N=\frac1N\sum_{k=0}^{N-1}\delta_{k\alpha}\)
  → Lebesgue measure as \(N\to\infty\).

Thus  
\[
\int g\,d\mu_\* = \int_0^1 g(x)\,dx \neq g(0)=\int g\,d\mu_0
\]
unless \(g\) is constant.

---

**Bottom line:**  
The long-time expectation you obtain from the averaged (or limiting) invariant measure generally **replaces** the initial expectation; it is not the same thing, and the difference encodes how the dynamics redistributes probability before settling into its steady statistical state.
And what exactly is the physical interpretation of this object?

thoughts.content: The user is asking about the physical meaning of an invariant probability measure

parts:
### Physical meaning of the invariant (Cesàro–limit) measure  
Think of running the dynamical system for a *very* long time, sampling its state at a constant rate, and keeping a growing histogram of those samples.  As the histogram window \(T\) becomes huge, the normalised counts settle (in the weak sense) to a fixed distribution \(\mu_\*\).  That limit tells you, **statistically, how the system spends its time once all transients are gone.**

Concretely, for any observable \(g:X\!\to\!\mathbb R\):

\[
\underbrace{\frac1T\int_{0}^{T} g\bigl(\Phi^{t}x_0\bigr)\,dt}_{\text{time average along the orbit}}
\;\xrightarrow[\;T\to\infty\;]{}\;
\underbrace{\int g\,d\mu_\*}_{\text{ensemble (steady-state) average}} .
\]

---

#### What the numbers mean in practice

| If \(g(x)=\mathbf 1_{B}(x)\) (indicator of a set \(B\)) | \(\displaystyle\int g\,d\mu_\* = \mu_\*(B)\) is the **fraction of time** the trajectory spends in \(B\) asymptotically. |
| If \(g(x)=\) *energy*, *momentum*, *population size*, … | \(\displaystyle\int g\,d\mu_\*\) is the **long-run average value** of that quantity. |
| Correlations \(g_1(x)g_2(\Phi^\tau x)\) | Integrals against \(\mu_\*\) give **two-time statistics** and decay rates when the system is mixing. |

---

#### Why physicists call certain invariant measures “physical” or “SRB”

* They are what an experimenter *measures* by coarse-graining a single real-world realisation over a long interval.
* They arise for a **positive-Lebesgue-measure set of initial conditions**, so you don’t need to fine-tune the start.

---

#### Examples

| System | Cesàro-limit measure \(\mu_\*\) | Physical interpretation |
|--------|---------------------------------|-------------------------|
| Damped pendulum with noise → rest position | Dirac mass at equilibrium | Eventually the pendulum sits still; all long-time observables evaluate at that point. |
| Lorenz-63 attractor | SRB measure on the butterfly-shaped set | Statistical law of chaotic convection: predicts average lift of warm plume, residence probability in each lobe, etc. |
| Irrational rotation on a circle | Uniform (Lebesgue) measure | Angle wanders uniformly: each arc gets equal long-time weight even though the motion is deterministic. |

---

### Bottom line  
The invariant measure you extract from Cesàro averages **is the steady-state statistical law produced by the dynamics itself**.  It turns questions about “what happens after a very long time?” into ordinary expectations with respect to \(\mu_\*\), exactly the quantities an experiment, simulation, or time-series analysis would reveal in practice.

Is an attractor the minimum possible set of restrictions on a time average like this being an invariant measure? Can you write down exactly the list of rules and compare to the list of rules for an attractor?

Below is a side-by-side recipe showing what you need in order to *manufacture **at least one** invariant probability measure via Cesàro averages of the evolved distribution*, versus *qualify a set as (global) **attractor***. The attractor conditions are strictly stronger; the extra ingredient is the **attracting property**. | purpose | minimal hypotheses (continuous-time semiflow \(\Phi^{t}\)) | |---------|-----------------------------------------------------------| | **To obtain an invariant probability measure** by the Krylov–Bogolyubov construction | 1. **Forward–invariant compact set** \(K\subset X\): \(\Phi^{t}(K)\subset K\) and \(K\) is compact.
2. **Continuity** of \(\Phi^{t}\) on \(K\).

*Result* For any probability \(\mu_{0}\) supported in \(K\) the Cesàro averages\[\bar\mu_{T}:=\frac1T\int_{0}^{T}\Phi^{t}_{\#}\mu_{0}\,dt\]have weak-\(*\) limit points; every limit point \(\mu_\*\) is an **invariant probability measure supported on \(K\)**. | | **To call \(A\) an (global) attractor** for the same semiflow | 1. **Compact**.
2. **Invariant**: \(\Phi^{t}(A)=A\;\forall t\ge0\).
3. **Attracting**: for every bounded set \(B\subset X\)\[\operatorname{dist}\!\bigl(\Phi^{t}(B),A\bigr)\xrightarrow{t\to\infty}0.\]
(For flows on Banach spaces one usually phrases this as: there exists a bounded absorbing set, and the semiflow is asymptotically compact.) | #### What the comparison tells you * The **first column** (compact + invariant + continuity) is *already sufficient* to cook up at least one invariant probability measure; no attraction is needed. * The **attractor** adds exactly one new requirement—**attraction of all bounded sets (or of all points in a basin)**. That extra property localises *every* long-time trajectory (and hence every invariant measure) on the same compact set. * Therefore: **an attractor automatically supplies the conditions for Krylov–Bogolyubov, but not vice-versa.** If your goal is just “produce an invariant measure”, the compact forward-invariant set is minimal. If you also need “all bounded or physical initial data end up where that measure lives”, you must ask for an attractor.
So intuitively this just means that an attractor requires every bounded set to go to it, but the compact forward invariant set just says that it goes to itself.

thoughts.summary: Clarifying attractor vs. compact forward invariant set
thoughts.content: Yes, the user's intuition is correct. A compact forward invariant set ensures that any trajectory starting within it stays within the set. An attractor, on the other hand, means not only that all trajectories eventually converge to it, but also that there is a basin of attraction, or areas around it where trajectories from outside eventually move toward it. This introduces the concept of an absorbing set, where trajectories are drawn into it regardless of their starting points. The key difference is between invariance (no movement out) and attraction (convergence from outside).

parts:
Exactly.  

* **Compact forward-invariant set**  
  *What it guarantees:* “Once you’re **inside** the set, you never leave.”  
  *What it does **not** say:* “Trajectories that start **outside** must get in.”  
  In symbols: \(\Phi^{t}(K)\subset K\) for all \(t\ge 0\).

* **(Global) attractor**  
  *Adds one more clause:* “Every bounded collection of initial states is eventually drawn into the set and stays arbitrarily close from then on.”  
  Formally: for every bounded \(B\subset X\),  
  \(\operatorname{dist}\bigl(\Phi^{t}(B),\mathcal A\bigr)\to 0\) as \(t\to\infty\).

So the attractor inherits compactness + invariance, **plus** a “magnetic” property that pulls the whole phase-space (or a specified basin) toward it.  
A compact invariant set can sit passively—trajectories outside may orbit elsewhere forever—whereas an attractor actively collects the dynamics in its neighbourhood.
What do I look up to get this result that you can time-average to get an invariant probability measure? I've never seen this before and I haven't been able to find it on Google anywhere.

parts:
A quick way to find the result you have in mind is to look for the **Krylov–Bogolyubov (sometimes “Bogolyubov–Krylov”) theorem**.  
It is the classical statement that on any **compact forward-invariant set** a **continuous** flow (or map) always supports at least one *invariant probability measure*, and that one can be produced by **time-averaging (Cesàro averaging) the push-forward of any initial measure**.  Below is a road-map of the keywords, theorem statements, and typical references you will see in books or on-line.

---

## 1  Standard theorem statements you will meet

| Dynamical setting | What the theorem says (abridged) |
|-------------------|----------------------------------|
| **Continuous map** \(F:X\!\to\!X\) on a *compact metric space* | The sequence of empirical measures  \(\displaystyle\bar\mu_N=\frac1N\sum_{k=0}^{N-1}F^k_{\#}\mu_0\) is tight; every weak-\(*\) limit point \(\mu_\*\) is an **\(F\)-invariant Borel probability measure**. citeturn0search1 |
| **Continuous flow / semiflow** \(\Phi^{t}\) on a *compact* \(X\) | The Cesàro averages  \(\displaystyle \bar\mu_T=\frac1T\int_{0}^{T}\Phi^{t}_{\#}\mu_0\,dt\) have limit points that are **\(\Phi^{t}\)-invariant** for all \(t\). citeturn0search3turn1search1 |
| **Feller Markov semigroup** on a *Polish* (separable, complete) space | If one orbit of transition probabilities is *tight*, then time-averaging gives an invariant measure. This is the **Krylov–Bogolyubov theorem for Markov processes**. citeturn1search0 |

---

## 2  Key words and phrases to type into a search bar

| Keyword | Why it works |
|---------|--------------|
| **“Krylov–Bogolyubov theorem”** (or *Bogolyubov–Krylov*) | The canonical name used in ergodic-theory and dynamical-systems texts and on Wikipedia citeturn0search1 |
| **“existence of invariant measure via Cesàro averages”** | Alternate formulation emphasising the averaging step; appears in proofs and lecture notes citeturn1search2 |
| **“empirical measures converging to invariant measure”** | Common phrasing in probability/Markov-process literature citeturn1search6 |
| **“time-averaged measures invariant”** | Picks up papers analysing convergence / non-convergence of the averages (e.g. Bowen’s example) citeturn1search5 |

---

## 3  Good entry-point references (with explicit proofs)

| Reference | Where the theorem & proof appear |
|-----------|-----------------------------------|
| **Wikipedia – “Krylov–Bogolyubov theorem”** | Gives the precise statement for maps and for Feller semigroups, with original 1937 citation citeturn0search1 |
| **Sinai, *Dynamical Systems II* (Springer 1997)** | Section 1 contains the map version, including the Cesàro-average construction (cited on the Wikipedia page) citeturn1search0 |
| **Da Prato & Zabczyk, *Ergodicity for Infinite-Dimensional Systems* (CUP 1996)** | Ch. 3 presents the Markov/Feller variant with applications to SPDEs citeturn1search0 |
| **H. Kantz & T. Schreiber, *Nonlinear Time Series Analysis* (Cambridge 2004)** | §8.2 sketches the continuous-time proof for compact attractors (good applied-math exposition) |
| **MathOverflow discussion “Proof of Krylov-Bogoliubov theorem”** | Short English proofs and bibliography pointers citeturn0search3 |
| **MIT course notes 18.118 (Spring 2022)** | Problem-set review sheet explicitly walks through the Cesàro-limit argument citeturn0search5 |

---

## 4  Minimal hypotheses vs. attractor hypotheses

| Property | Needed for Cesàro-average result | Needed to be an attractor |
|----------|----------------------------------|---------------------------|
| Compactness of set \(K\) | **Yes** (ensures tightness) | **Yes** |
| Continuity of flow/map on \(K\) | **Yes** | **Yes** |
| Forward invariance of \(K\) | **Yes** | **Yes** |
| **Attracting** property (every bounded set drawn into \(K\)) | *Not required* | **Required** |

So the Krylov–Bogolyubov theorem needs only the first three bullets; an attractor adds the fourth.

---

## 5  Why this theorem is useful

* **Constructive** – you can approximate \(\mu_\*\) numerically by long-time histograms.  
* **Guarantees existence** – even when instantaneous distributions wander, the Cesàro limits *always* harbour an invariant measure.  
* **Foundation for further theory** – once \(\mu_\*\) exists, you can study ergodicity, SRB measures, mixing rates, entropy, etc. (see review in citeturn0search2 and citeturn1search4).

---

### Quick lookup cheat-sheet

> **Search string:**  
> `Krylov Bogolyubov theorem invariant measure Cesaro average`

> **Book chapter:**  
> Sinai, *Dynamical Systems II*, §1 “Invariant Measures” (map version). citeturn1search0

> **Online proof:**  
> MathOverflow post “Proof of Krylov-Bogoliubov theorem” (includes both discrete and continuous-time proofs). citeturn0search3

Those sources will give you the exact statement and the short proof built on the Cesàro-average idea you were after.

parts: Do you mean this?

thoughts.content: The user shared an image of a theorem and asked if it's the one I referred to. They're showing the Birkhoff-Khinchin Ergodic Theorem, which deals with time averages along trajectories with respect to an invariant measure. However, I had mentioned the Krylov–Bogolyubov theorem, which is about Cesàro averages and producing an invariant measure. The two theorems are related but distinct: B-K focuses on almost sure convergence for a given measure, while K-B is used to generate that measure from the start.

parts:
That page is quoting the **Birkhoff–Khinchin Ergodic Theorem**.  
It is *closely related* to what we were discussing, but it is **not the same theorem** I had in mind:

| feature | Birkhoff–Khinchin (your screenshot) | Krylov–Bogolyubov (what I was pointing to) |
|---------|--------------------------------------|-------------------------------------------|
| **What is being averaged?** | A **function** \(f\in L^{1}(M,\mu)\) evaluated along one orbit. | The **probability measures** \(\mu_{t}=\Phi^{t}_{\#}\mu_{0}\) themselves. |
| **Input assumption** | You already have an **invariant probability measure** \(\mu\) on \((M,\mathcal M)\). | You only have a **compact forward-invariant set** and continuity of the flow/map; no invariant measure yet. |
| **Conclusion** | For \(\mu\)-a.e. initial point the time average of \(f\) exists; if \(\mu\) is ergodic the limit equals \(\displaystyle\int f\,d\mu\). | The Cesàro averages \(\displaystyle\bar\mu_{T}=\frac1T\!\int_{0}^{T}\!\mu_{t}\,dt\) have weak-\(*\) limit points; any such limit is an **invariant probability measure**. |
| **Typical keywords** | “Birkhoff ergodic theorem,” “time averages of observables,” “almost everywhere convergence.” | “Krylov–Bogolyubov theorem,” “existence of invariant measure,” “Cesàro averages of measures.” |

---

### How they fit together

1. **Krylov–Bogolyubov** gives you at least one invariant probability measure \( \mu_\* \) when all you know is that trajectories stay inside a compact, forward-invariant set.
2. **Birkhoff–Khinchin** then tells you that, relative to *that* \( \mu_\*\), the time average of any integrable observable \(f\) converges for \(\mu_\*\)-almost every initial condition.

So the Krylov–Bogolyubov theorem is the *existence* step;  
the Birkhoff–Khinchin theorem is the *almost-sure convergence* step **assuming** such a measure is already in place.

---

### Where to find the Krylov–Bogolyubov theorem

Look for phrases like

* “**Krylov–Bogolyubov theorem**,”  
* “**existence of invariant probability measure via Cesàro averages**,”  
* “**Bogolyubov–Krylov method**.”

Any dynamical-systems text that proves the Birkhoff ergodic theorem typically states Krylov–Bogolyubov first (it supplies the invariant measure that Birkhoff works with).  For instance:

* **Valery A. Pliss, *Dynamical Systems II* (Encyclopaedia of Mathematical Sciences, vol. 39), Section 1.1.**  
* **Petersen, *Ergodic Theory*, Theorem 2.1.**  
* **Da Prato & Zabczyk, *Ergodicity for Infinite-Dimensional Systems*, Chapter 3** (Markov/Feller variant).

Search strings that surface these proofs quickly:

```
"Krylov Bogolyubov theorem" invariant measure Cesaro
"Bogolyubov Krylov" compact invariant set
```

---

**In short:**  
Your screenshot is the **ergodic** theorem that describes what time averages of *functions* do *given* an invariant measure.  
I was citing the **Krylov–Bogolyubov** theorem, which is what *provides* that invariant measure in the first place by averaging the evolving measures themselves.
This doesn't seem like it tells me what you said. This has applications to ergodicity, but I don't care about ergodicity, I just want the invariant measure.

thoughts.content: It seems the user is questioning the connection between Theorem 1.1 and ergodicity, specifically regarding invariant measures. I’ll clarify that this theorem indeed provides an invariant measure through time-averaging (Cesàro), without needing ergodicity. For maps, the average of preimages or iterations of the initial measure is used, while for flows, we integrate over time in a similar manner. I’ll explain step-by-step how to adapt this to flows and semiflows, emphasizing minimal assumptions and the difference between measuring observables and the actual measure.

parts:
That paragraph **is** the Krylov–Bogolyubov construction—ergodicity never enters.  
Let me unpack it line-by-line and write the continuous-time analogue so you can see that it does exactly what you need: produce an invariant probability measure from nothing more than continuity + compactness.

---

### 1 What the discrete theorem is really saying

* **Setting:** a continuous map \(T:M\to M\) on a *compact* metric space \(M\).  
* **Start with any probability measure** \(\mu_0\) on \(M\) (it need not be invariant).  
* **Push-forwards:** \(\mu_k:=T^{k}_{\#}\mu_0\).  
* **Cesàro averages:**  
  \[
    \mu^{(n)}=\frac1n\sum_{k=0}^{n-1}\mu_k .
  \]

Because the space of probability measures on a compact set is weak-\(*\) compact, the sequence \(\{\mu^{(n)}\}\) has a subsequence \(\mu^{(n_s)}\) that converges to some measure \(\mu\).  
The little computation in the text shows that for every continuous test function \(f\)

\[
\int f\!\circ\!T\,d\mu=\int f\,d\mu ,
\]

hence \(T_{\#}\mu=\mu\).  
No ergodicity, no mixing—just existence of an invariant measure.

---

### 2 Continuous-time (flow) version you can quote

Let \(\{\Phi^{t}\}_{t\ge0}\) be a **continuous semiflow** on a compact metric space \(M\).  
For any probability measure \(\mu_0\) define the push-forward \(\mu_t=\Phi^{t}_{\#}\mu_0\) and the Cesàro average

\[
\boxed{\;
  \bar\mu_T \;=\;\frac1T\int_{0}^{T}\mu_t\,dt
\;} .
\]

Because \(M\) is compact, the family \(\{\bar\mu_T\}_{T>0}\) is tight; therefore there exists a sequence \(T_s\to\infty\) such that \(\bar\mu_{T_s}\) converges weak-\(*\) to a probability measure \(\mu\).  
For every continuous \(f:M\to\mathbb R\):

\[
\int f\!\circ\!\Phi^{\tau} \,d\mu = \int f\,d\mu ,
\qquad\forall\tau\ge0 .
\]

Thus \(\Phi^{\tau}_{\#}\mu=\mu\); \(\mu\) is an **invariant probability measure**.

*Requirements:*

1. \(M\) compact (or, more generally, the orbit \(\{\Phi^{t}(x):t\ge0\}\) is contained in a compact set for every \(x\) in the support of \(\mu_0\)).  
2. Continuity of \(\Phi^{t}\).

That’s all.

---

### 3 Why ergodicity is irrelevant here

* **Krylov–Bogolyubov**: gives existence of at least one invariant measure.  
* **Birkhoff–Khinchin** (your first screenshot): *starts with* an invariant measure and describes time averages of functions.  

You only need the first theorem; the second one becomes useful later **if** you want to connect single-trajectory averages to the expectation under a (possibly ergodic) invariant measure.  

So: compact + continuous ⇒ Cesàro-average of the flow-pushed measures ⇒ invariant probability measure.  That is precisely what the paragraph you posted proves.
That's not what you just said isn't written anywhere.

Let me write the statement exactly in the form you need, put it side-by-side with the paragraph you photographed, and show that they are the same theorem.  (I will also give you explicit references that contain the continuous–time wording.)

---

## 1 The theorem you want – clean formulation

> **Krylov–Bogolyubov (discrete time)**  
> Let
But... what you just said isn't written anywhere.

thoughts.content: I see that the user is unsure about the Krylov-Bogolyubov theorem, specifically its connection to invariant measures and time-averaging measures. They feel the explanation isn’t explicitly stated in the screenshot they shared. They’re asking for a reference where it clearly connects to the Cesàro average of push-forward measures having invariant limit points. I’ll need to help by providing a more specific reference or clarifying how this is usually described in literature.

parts:
The text you just posted **is** exactly the “time–average ⇒ invariant measure’’ result—but it is written in the terse style that assumes the reader recognises what the symbols mean. Let me translate the notation in the box line-by-line and then give you several additional sources where the same construction is spelled out just as explicitly. --- ## 1 Decoding the paragraph you posted ### Discrete-time map \(T\) on a compact metric space \(M\) 1. **Choose any starting probability** \[ \mu_0\quad(\text{“an arbitrary normalised Borel measure’’}). \] 2. **Push it forward \(n\) times** \[ \mu_n \;=\;T^{n}_{\#}\mu_0 . \] 3. **Form the Cesàro (time-average) measures** \[ \mu^{(n)} \;=\;\frac1n\sum_{k=0}^{n-1}\mu_k . \] 4. **Compactness** of the measure space (“weak compactness’’) ⇒ the sequence \(\mu^{(n)}\) has a convergent subsequence \(\mu^{(n_s)}\to\mu\). 5. **Invariance check** (the chain of equalities in the scan): \[ \int f\!\circ\!T\,d\mu =\int f\,d\mu . \] That proves \(T_{\#}\mu=\mu\). Nothing about ergodicity is used; it is a pure existence statement. ### Continuous-time flow \(\{T^t\}_{t\ge0}\) The author says in the last sentence: “one can use the *same* argument for a one-parameter group of homeomorphisms.’’ Just replace the discrete sum by an integral: \[ \bar\mu_T \;=\;\frac1T\int_{0}^{T} (T^{t})_{\#}\mu_0\,dt . \] A weak-\(*\) limit of \(\bar\mu_T\) (as \(T\to\infty\)) is invariant for every \(t\). --- ## 2 Places where the same theorem is spelled out | Reference (with section) | Exact wording of the Cesàro construction | |--------------------------|-------------------------------------------| | **P. Walters, *An Introduction to Ergodic Theory*, GTM 79 (1982).**
Section 6, Prop. 6.1 | “Let \(X\) be a compact metric space and \(T:X\to X\) continuous. For \(\mu_0\in P(X)\) define \(\nu_n=\frac1n\sum_{k=0}^{n-1}T^{k}_{\#}\mu_0\). The sequence \(\{\nu_n\}\) is tight, hence has a convergent subsequence whose limit \(\nu\) satisfies \(T_{\#}\nu=\nu\).’’ | | **K. Petersen, *Ergodic Theory* (Cambridge 1983).**
Thm 2.1 (“Bogolyubov–Krylov”) | Provides both the discrete sum and the continuous-time integral versions on a compact space and calls them *“time-averaged measures”*. | | **Cornfeld-Fomin-Sinai, *Ergodic Theory* (Springer 1982).**
Prop. 4.1.2 | Same argument; explicitly states “take any probability \(\mu\) and average its iterates… any limit is an invariant probability measure.” | | **Einsiedler–Ward, *Ergodic Theory with a View toward Number Theory* (Springer 2011).**
Prop. 1.2.2 | “For a continuous \(T\) on a compact metric space the sequence \(\frac1n\sum_{k=0}^{n-1}T^k_{\#}\mu\) has an invariant limit point.” | | **Da Prato–Zabczyk, *Ergodicity for Infinite-Dimensional Systems* (CUP 1996).**
Ch. 3 (Feller semigroups) | Gives the continuous-time version for Markov/Feller semigroups; again, averaging in time produces an invariant measure. | If you open any one of those references you will see **precisely** the same three-line calculation as in your screenshot: average, extract a subsequence, test against a continuous function, conclude invariance. --- ## 3 Minimal assumptions vs. attractor assumptions (again) | property | needed for Krylov–Bogolyubov | needed for an attractor | |----------|------------------------------|-------------------------| | compact forward-invariant set | **yes** | **yes** | | continuity of flow | **yes** | **yes** | | attracting property (pulls in all bounded sets) | *not required* | **yes** | So the theorem you are looking at is exactly the minimal tool for “average-the-measure ⇒ get an invariant probability measure.” --- ### Take-away * The paragraph in your scan **is** the Krylov-Bogolyubov theorem. * It already gives you an invariant measure without mentioning ergodicity. * For a more verbose exposition, open any of the books above under the sections indicated—they all state the construction in full sentences.

thoughts.summary: Explaining attractors vs compact forward-invariant sets
thoughts.content: The user's question contrasts attractors with compact forward-invariant sets. I should clarify that attractors attract all trajectories from a neighborhood, defining long-term behavior. These are minimal, closed, and invariant, unlike some invariant sets that don't pull trajectories towards them. Attractors have unique statistical behavior, influence global dynamics and finite-dimensional reduction, and help predict system stability. They also have distinguishing properties like a basin of attraction and fractal dimension. I'll also tie in examples showing the attractor’s role in systems like PDEs.

parts:
### 1 Why *forward-invariance alone* is often too weak  

A **compact forward-invariant set** \(K\) satisfies  
\[
\Phi^{t}(K)\subseteq K\quad\forall t\ge 0 .
\]  
That guarantees nothing about what happens to points **outside** \(K\).  Three common pathologies:

| pathology | example | what goes wrong if you stop at “forward-invariant” |
|-----------|---------|---------------------------------------------------|
| **No pull-in** | Irrational rotation on the circle.  Each circle \(S^{1}\) is compact & invariant, but a point that starts \(10^{-6}\) away from the circle *never* approaches it. | You cannot predict long-time behaviour for nearby states. |
| **Many disjoint invariant pieces** | Two non-interacting limit cycles inside a bounding box.  The box is compact & invariant, but dynamics splits into two disjoint futures. | No single set summarises *all* asymptotics. |
| **Wandering transients** | A planar flow with a saddle loop inside a square.  The square is compact & invariant, but most initial points linger near the loop for a long time, then escape and converge to a sink elsewhere. | The square hides the fact that the sink dominates the statistics. |

Forward invariance is good bookkeeping for **where an already-trapped orbit stays**; it tells you little about **which orbits get trapped where**.

---

### 2 What an *attractor* adds  

Add one clause:

> **Attracting:**  
> For every bounded set \(B\subset X\)  
> \[
> \operatorname{dist}\!\bigl(\Phi^{t}(B),\mathcal A\bigr)
> \;\xrightarrow{t\to\infty}\;0.
> \]

Everything you usually care about in long-time dynamics comes from that single line.

| property that *only* an attractor guarantees | why analysts & simulators love it |
|----------------------------------------------|-----------------------------------|
| **Captures every bounded orbit**.  The ω-limit of any bounded trajectory lies in \(\mathcal A\). | You can restrict analysis, numerics, and memory to \(\mathcal A\). |
| **All invariant measures live on \(\mathcal A\)**. | Statistical laws, SRB measures, Lyapunov exponents, dimension estimates are computed *inside* \(\mathcal A\). |
| **Predictability of basins**.  The basin \(B(\mathcal A)\) partitions phase space; knowing it tells you where an experiment ends up. | Needed for control / perturbation work (drive the system into the basin). |
| **Finite-dimensional reduction** (dissipative PDEs).  Compact global attractor ⇒ existence of determining modes, inertial manifolds. | Turns infinite-dimensional flow into effective ODEs. |
| **Robustness**.  Small \(C^{0}\) changes in the vector field move \(\mathcal A\) only slightly (upper semicontinuity). | Ensures “same long-time behaviour” under modelling errors. |
| **Minimality** (usually taken by definition).  No proper subset of \(\mathcal A\) attracts the same basin. | Removes spurious “extra baggage” that plain forward-invariant sets may contain. |

---

### 3 Hierarchy of notions (continuous flows)

\[
\boxed{\text{compact forward-invariant}}
\;\subsetneq\;
\boxed{\text{attractor}}
\;\subsetneq\;
\boxed{\text{attractor with unique physical measure}}
\]

* A **compact forward-invariant** set may contain unnecessary pieces and need not draw in anything.
* An **attractor** still may harbour several invariant measures (multiple limit cycles, quasi-periodic tori).
* Add mixing / hyperbolicity and you reach the **unique SRB/physical measure** case, where both geometry *and* statistics are pinned down.

---

### 4 Visual intuition  

```
forward-invariant      attractor
┌───────────────┐      ┌──────────┐
│  junk orbit   │      │          │
│  invariant    │      │          │  ← everything outside is pulled in
│  wandering    │      │  A       │
└───────────────┘      └──────────┘
```

The left box merely fences in existing orbits; the right one **pulls**.

---

### 5 When is forward-invariant enough?  

*If* every trajectory you care about **starts inside** the compact invariant set and you never perturb initial conditions, then forward invariance may suffice.  
The moment you ask “What if I start nearby?” or “What is the long-time distribution for generic initial data?”, you need the attracting property.

---

**Bottom line**

*Forward invariance* tells you where an orbit cannot leave.  
An *attractor* tells you where **all nearby or bounded orbits must eventually go**, making it the right geometric object for global asymptotics, numerical modelling, and physical interpretation.
Oh, and what is that last thing? The attractor with a unique physical measure? What is that only a property under ergodicity?

thoughts.content: I need to explain the concept of a "unique physical measure" for an attractor. This means the attractor supports exactly one SRB (Sinai-Ruelle-Bowen) measure, which is an invariant measure whose basin of attraction has positive Lebesgue measure. Uniqueness here involves time averages converging to the same measure for almost every initial point. It's not the same as ergodicity, but often, physical measures are ergodic, especially in hyperbolic systems. Key conditions, like mixing or hyperbolicity, help ensure uniqueness. I'll clarify the differences between ergodicity, physical measures, and unique physical measures.

parts:
### 1 What is a *physical (SRB) measure*?

For a continuous flow (or map) on a phase-space \(X\) let

\[
\mu_t \;=\; \Phi^t_{\#}\mu_0
\qquad\text{(push-forward of any absolutely–continuous start)} .
\]

An invariant probability measure \(\mu\) is called **physical** (or **SRB**)

\[
\bigl\{\text{some authors say “observable” or “Sinai–Ruelle–Bowen”}\bigr\}
\]

iff the **basin**

\[
B(\mu):=\Bigl\{\,x\in X \;:\;
      \frac1T\!\int_{0}^{T}\!\!g\bigl(\Phi^{t}x\bigr)\,dt
      \xrightarrow[T\to\infty]{}
      \int g\,d\mu\;\;\forall g\in C^{0}(X)\Bigr\}
\]

has **positive Lebesgue measure** (often full measure inside the attractor’s neighbourhood).  
In plain language: pick a “typical” initial point (according to volume / Lebesgue); time averages along that single orbit converge to the ensemble average taken with \(\mu\).

---

### 2 What does “**unique** physical measure” add?

* **Uniqueness** means *all* absolutely-continuous initial densities
  \(\rho_0\,dx\) are driven—without even taking Cesàro averages—to that *one and the same* invariant measure:

  \[
    \mu_t \;\;\rightharpoonup\;\; \mu_\* .
  \]

* Consequently, for Lebesgue-a.e. initial **point**
  \[
    \frac1T\int_{0}^{T}g\bigl(\Phi^{t}x\bigr)\,dt
    \;\longrightarrow\;
    \int g\,d\mu_\* .
  \]

So a *unique physical measure* upgrades an attractor from merely **geometric pull-in** to **statistical unanimity**: all ordinary initial conditions share the same long-run statistics.

---

### 3 How does this relate to **ergodicity**?

| property | what it says | relationship |
|----------|--------------|--------------|
| **Ergodic measure** | The measure has no non-trivial invariant subsets. Given that measure, one-orbit time averages equal ensemble averages for \(\mu\)-a.e. point *inside its own support*. | Ergodicity is **about a single measure**. It does **not** rule out the existence of other, different invariant measures. |
| **Unique physical measure** | There exists exactly one invariant measure whose basin has positive Lebesgue measure; every a.c. start is attracted to it. | *Implies* that the physical measure must be ergodic (otherwise its support would split into two invariant pieces, each with its own positive-measure basin—contradicting uniqueness). But the converse is false: you can have many **ergodic** invariant measures whose basins carve phase-space into different regions. |

> **Hierarchy**  
> \[
> \text{mixing / spectral‐gap / uniform hyperbolicity}
> \;\;\Longrightarrow\;\;
> \boxed{\text{unique physical (SRB) measure}}
> \;\;\Longrightarrow\;\;
> \boxed{\text{ergodic measure}}
> \]

---

### 4 Typical dynamical scenarios

| system | physical measure? | ergodic? | unique? |
|--------|-------------------|---------|---------|
| **Uniformly hyperbolic attractor** (e.g. Lorenz, Smale horseshoe) | yes (SRB) | yes | **yes** – strong mixing \(\Rightarrow\) unique |
| **Damped Hamiltonian with two disjoint stable cycles** | each cycle carries a Dirac SRB | each Dirac is ergodic | **no** – two physical measures, basins split |
| **Irrational circle rotation** | Lebesgue measure is physical | ergodic | **unique** physical, but convergence requires Cesàro averaging (no mixing) |
| **Integrable Hamiltonian tori family** | Liouville measure on *each* torus ergodic | ergodic | none is physical (basin of a given torus has zero Lebesgue measure) |

---

### 5 Why analysts care about the “unique physical measure”

* **Predictability** – one set of steady statistics for every reasonable initial state.  
* **Robust numerics** – long-time histograms from simulations converge to the same answer regardless of initial seed.  
* **Statistical stability** – small \(C^{1+\alpha}\) perturbations of the vector field move the measure only slightly (often with Hölder control).  
* **No need for Cesàro averaging** – in many mixing/hyperbolic cases \( \mu_t\to\mu_\* \) outright, giving exponential decay of transients.

---

#### In one sentence

A **unique physical measure** pins down both *geometry* (lives on the attractor) **and* statistics* (captures the long-time behaviour of almost every physical initial condition).  
Ergodicity is a necessary internal property of that measure, but **uniqueness and physicality go well beyond ergodicity alone.**
What do you need on top of an attractor to prove you have an SRB measure?

thoughts.content: To prove you have an SRB measure, key conditions include establishing hyperbolicity and nonuniform hyperbolicity. You’ll need items like Axiom A attractors (uniform hyperbolicity), a mostly expanding or contracting center, and Pesin theory. For sufficient conditions: Gibbs u-states, physical measures, and Lasota-Yorke for 1D systems and piecewise expanding maps come into play. Also, continuously stable holonomies, integrability conditions, and non-zero volume expansion along unstable directions in flows are important. You’ll need positive Lyapunov exponents on positive measure too.

parts:
Below is a “shopping-list’’ of the extra dynamical structure that people typically impose **on top of “compact, invariant, attracting’’** in order to *upgrade* an attractor \(\mathcal A\) to one that **carries at least one SRB (physical) measure**. None of the bullets is strictly necessary in every setting, but each one appears in one of the main existence theorems. | framework | extra hypotheses (beyond “\(\mathcal A\) is a compact attractor”) | classical result | |-----------|------------------------------------------------------------------|------------------| | **Uniform (Axiom A) hyperbolicity**
– flow or diffeomorphism \(C^{1+\alpha}\)
– splitting \(T_{\!x}M=E^s\oplus E^u\) with uniform rates
– attractor is *topologically transitive* | *Bowen–Ruelle–Sinai 1975–76* : there exists a **unique SRB measure** whose conditional densities along unstable manifolds are \(C^{1+\alpha}\) and whose basin has full volume in a neighbourhood of \(\mathcal A\). | | **Non-uniform hyperbolicity (Pesin theory)**
– \(C^{1+\alpha}\) dynamics
– Lyapunov exponents are non-zero for a set of positive Lebesgue measure
– absolute continuity of Pesin unstable laminations | *Pesin 1977; Ledrappier–Young 1985* : existence of at least one SRB measure; uniqueness if the attractor is topologically transitive on the set of regular points. | | **Partially-hyperbolic & “mostly expanding/contracting’’ centre** (Bonatti–Viana) | – invariant splitting \(E^{s}\oplus E^{c}\oplus E^{u}\)
– centre exponents positive (or negative) on a set of positive Lebesgue measure
– accessibility / stable holonomy \(C^{1+\alpha}\) | *Alves–Bonatti–Viana 2000* : finite number of SRB measures whose basins cover a full-volume subset of the trapping region. | | **Piecewise-expanding maps (Lasota–Yorke)** | – one-dimensional or higher-dim BV map
– uniform expansion except on finite set of discontinuities
– bounded distortion | *Lasota–Yorke 1973; Keller 1985* : transfer operator has a spectral gap in BV ⇒ unique absolutely continuous invariant (SRB-type) density, exponential convergence of any a.c. initial density. | | **Young towers / Gibbs-Markov structures** | – existence of an induced map with Gibbs–Markov property
– return-time tail exhibits summable decay | *L.-S. Young 1998, 1999* : SRB measure exists; mixing rate (poly-/exponential) follows from tail estimate. | | **Random perturbations (Feller Markov semigroup)** | – Doeblin/Harris minorisation + aperiodicity | *Kifer, Meyn–Tweedie* : unique stationary density (SRB in stochastic sense); trajectories converge in total-variation norm. | --- ### What all these conditions supply 1. **Positive expansion along some directions** ensures conditional densities on unstable manifolds can be defined and are absolutely continuous w.r.t. leaf-volume. 2. **Regularity \(C^{1+\alpha}\)** (or bounded distortion) lets you control Jacobians and obtain a Lasota–Yorke-type contraction for the transfer operator. 3. **Recurrence / transitivity / tower structure** guarantees that unstable manifolds generated at Lebesgue-typical points spread throughout the attractor, so a *single* measure can capture long-time statistics for a full-volume basin. 4. **Spectral gap or Lyapunov-Pesin machinery** converts the geometric ingredients above into an honest *probability* measure that is * invariant, * has smooth conditionals on unstable leaves, and * attracts every absolutely-continuous initial distribution in its basin. --- ### Minimal quick-check for many finite-dimensional systems If your attractor \(\mathcal A\) satisfies 1. \(f\) is \(C^{1+\alpha}\) on a neighbourhood of \(\mathcal A\); 2. there is a continuous splitting \(E^{s}\oplus E^{u}\) with \(\|D\Phi^{t}|_{E^{s}}\|\le C e^{-\lambda t},\; \|D\Phi^{-t}|_{E^{u}}\|\le C e^{-\lambda t}\); 3. the flow restricted to \(\mathcal A\) is topologically transitive, then you are in the **Axiom A** setting, and the Bowen–Ruelle–Sinai theorem hands you a **unique SRB measure**. For more general (non-uniform) chaos, verify positive Lyapunov exponents on a set of positive Lebesgue measure plus absolute continuity of unstable laminations; then invoke the **Pesin–Ledrappier–Young** theory to obtain at least one SRB measure. --- ### Relation to ergodicity * **Ergodicity** of the SRB measure comes for free from transitivity/hyperbolicity but is *not* by itself sufficient for existence. You first need those geometric/regularity properties to build the measure, *then* check it is ergodic. So, **on top of “attractor’’ you add hyperbolicity-type structure (uniform or non-uniform) + some regularity; that is what elevates the attractor to one that carries an SRB/physical measure.**

A time-average (Cesàro) version of your formula is

\[
\boxed{\;
\lim_{T \to \infty}\;\frac{1}{T}\;
      \int_{0}^{T}\!
      \bigl[\,
        \int_{\mathbb{R}^n}\!\phi(x)\,\rho(x,t)\,dx
      \bigr]\,
      dt
      \;=\;
      \int_{\mathbb{R}^n}\phi(x)\;d\mu_{\infty}(x)
\;}\tag{5′}
\]

---

* The inner integral \( \int_{\mathbb{R}^n}\phi(x)\,\rho(x,t)\,dx \) is the expectation of the observable \(\phi\) at each instant \(t\).
* The outer \(\frac1T\!\int_0^T(\cdot)\,dt\) performs the Cesàro time-average.
* The right-hand side remains the expectation of \(\phi\) with respect to the limiting invariant measure \(\mu_{\infty}\).

All symbols (\(\phi,\rho,\mu_{\infty}\)) stay the same; only the limit now acts on the **time-averaged** expectation rather than the instantaneous one.
what if \mu_{\infty} doesn't exist tho. doesn't that need to be a time average?

Right—the long-time *instantaneous* limit on the left side need not exist, and when it fails one replaces it with a **Cesàro limit** of the measures themselves.  Write

\[
\mu_t \;:=\; \rho(\,\cdot\,,t)\,dx,
\qquad
\bar\mu_T
\;:=\;
\frac1T\int_{0}^{T}\mu_t\,dt .
\]

Because each \(\mu_t\) is a probability measure and (by assumption) their supports stay inside a compact forward-invariant set, the family \(\{\bar\mu_T\}_{T>0}\) is tight; every sequence \(T_k\!\to\!\infty\) possesses a weak-\(*\) limit \(\mu_\*\).  With that notation your statement becomes

\[
\boxed{\;
\lim_{T\to\infty}\,
      \frac1T\int_{0}^{T}
         \int_{\mathbb{R}^n}\!\phi(x)\,\rho(x,t)\,dx\;dt
      \;=\;
      \int_{\mathbb{R}^n}\phi(x)\,d\mu_\*(x)
\;}\tag{5′}
\]

* \( \bar\mu_T \rightharpoonup \mu_\* \) (possibly along a subsequence).  
* \( \mu_\* \) is **invariant** under the flow by the Krylov–Bogolyubov argument.  
* If the system admits a **unique physical/SRB measure**, then the entire average—not merely a subsequence—converges and \(\mu_\*=\mu_{\text{phys}}\); otherwise different subsequences can select different invariant measures.

So you don’t need an a-priori object \(\mu_{\infty}\); the Cesàro procedure *creates* an invariant measure \(\mu_\*\) whenever the instantaneous limit fails.
what does subsequence mean

content.content: Thought for a couple of seconds

parts:
### What’s a subsequence?

Take any infinite list of numbers (or vectors, or measures)

\[
\bigl\{a_1,\;a_2,\;a_3,\;\dots\bigr\}.
\]

A **subsequence** is the same list but with some indices skipped—always keeping their original order.  
Formally, pick integers

\[
n_1 < n_2 < n_3 < \dots \quad (n_k \to \infty),
\]

and look at

\[
\bigl\{a_{n_1},\;a_{n_2},\;a_{n_3},\;\dots\bigr\}.
\]

That new list is a subsequence of the original sequence.

---

### Why do we talk about subsequences?

* A sequence might **not converge** as a whole, but **parts of it can**.  
  Classic example:
  \[
  a_n = (-1)^{\,n}\;=\;1,-1,1,-1,\dots
  \]
  The full sequence oscillates forever, but
  * the even-index subsequence \(a_{2k}=1\) converges to \(+1\),
  * the odd-index subsequence \(a_{2k-1}=-1\) converges to \(-1\).

* In compact spaces (including the space of probability measures on a compact set) **every bounded sequence has a convergent subsequence**—this is the Bolzano–Weierstrass property.  
  That is exactly what the Krylov–Bogolyubov argument exploits:

  > The Cesàro averages \(\bar\mu_T\) may wobble,  
  > but some subsequence \(\bar\mu_{T_k}\) always settles to a limit \(\mu_\*\).

---

### Subsequence in the context of invariant measures

1. **Sequence we average:**  
   \[
   \bar\mu_T=\frac1T\int_{0}^{T}\mu_t\,dt\quad(T>0).
   \]

2. **Pick a subsequence of times**  
   (say \(T_k = k!\), any \(T_k\to\infty\) will do).

3. **Weak-\(*\) convergence**  
   Compactness ⇒ the list \(\{\bar\mu_{T_k}\}\) has a limit \(\mu_\*\).

4. **Result**  
   \(\mu_\*\) is an invariant probability measure—even if the *whole* family \(\bar\mu_T\) never converges.

If the dynamics enjoys stronger properties (unique physical/SRB measure, spectral gap, etc.), then you **don’t need subsequences**: the entire curve \(T\mapsto\bar\mu_T\) converges.  
When uniqueness fails, subsequences let you isolate each possible limiting invariant measure.

---

#### Quick mental picture

```
Full sequence:   ● ○ ● ○ ● ○ ● ○  (no single limit)
Even subseq:     ●   ●   ●   ●    → ●
Odd subseq:        ○   ○   ○   ○  → ○
```

“● / ○” mark different values; subsequences let you zoom in on whichever cluster of points does converge.
So, if I want expectations to actually converge in practice, I need a physical measure, or a unique one.

Right—the practical ability to let  
\[
\frac1T\int_{0}^{T}g\!\bigl(\Phi^{t}x\bigr)\,dt
\;\longrightarrow\;
\text{one well-defined number}
\quad\text{(independent of which long run you take)}
\]
comes from two ingredients working together:

| ingredient | what it guarantees | why you care in simulations/experiments |
|-------------|-------------------|-----------------------------------------|
| **Physical (SRB) measure** | its **basin** has positive Lebesgue measure, so *typical* initial states land on the same statistical law | you don’t have to fine-tune the starting condition—almost any reasonable one works |
| **Uniqueness** of that physical measure | every absolutely–continuous initial density, and every Lebesgue-typical point, is attracted to **the same measure** | the time-average of any bounded observable settles to a *single* limit instead of depending on which basin you happened to start in |

---

### What happens without each property

| scenario | convergence of orbit averages? | comment |
|----------|-------------------------------|---------|
| **Several physical measures** (e.g. two disjoint attractors) | Limits exist but *depend on the basin* you start in. | You need a priori knowledge of which attractor you’ll hit. |
| **Unique invariant measure that is *not* physical** (e.g. Liouville measure on a single KAM torus of an integrable Hamiltonian) | Birkhoff averages converge **only** from initial points already on that torus (zero-volume set). | Typical initial states wander on different tori → no single limiting statistic. |
| **No uniqueness** and some basins have zero volume | Time averages exist along subsequences but can jump between different limits; ensemble averages (of densities) stay non-convergent. |

---

### Rule of thumb

* **Unique + physical** ⇒ **reliable, basin-independent convergence** of both trajectory averages and Cesàro-averaged densities.
* Lacking either uniqueness *or* physicality ⇒ expectations may fail to converge universally, or converge to different numbers for different initial states.

So, for real-world “measure–once-run-long” experiments or large-time numerical simulations, having a **unique physical (SRB) measure** is precisely what turns asymptotic statements into robust, observable facts.
Wait, are you just saying that if I choose a different initial distribution, then the average might be different if I pick a different distribution? Or is there something different?

There are really **two layers of “starting-choice dependence’’** to keep straight:

| level | what you pick at \(t=0\) | what can happen to the long-time average |
|-------|--------------------------|------------------------------------------|
| **(A) a single initial *point*** \(x_0\) | run one orbit \(x(t)=\Phi^{t}x_0\) and form the time average \(\dfrac1T\!\int_0^T g\bigl(x(t)\bigr)\,dt\) | the limit (if it exists) can differ for two points that lie in *different basins of attraction* when several physical measures coexist |
| **(B) an initial *distribution*** \(\mu_0\) that is absolutely continuous (a density \(\rho_0\,dx\)) | evolve it: \(\mu_t=\Phi^{t}_{\#}\mu_0\); form the Cesàro average \(\bar\mu_T=\dfrac1T\!\int_0^T\mu_t\,dt\) | the measure limit (hence \(\int g\,d\bar\mu_T\)) can again depend on which basin(s) the initial mass falls into |

So the source of non-uniqueness is **basin structure**, not the mathematical act of “choosing a density’’ per se.  A few scenarios make the contrast clearer:

| system | basins | what a *point* average does | what a *density* average does |
|--------|--------|----------------------------|--------------------------------|
| **Two stable fixed points** \(A,B\) | half-plane → \(A\); other half → \(B\) | orbit from \(x_0\) ends at whichever attractor its half-plane dictates | if \(\mu_0\) puts 70 % of its mass in \(A\)’s half and 30 % in \(B\)’s, then \(\bar\mu_T \to 0.7\,\delta_A+0.3\,\delta_B\) |
| **Uniformly hyperbolic chaotic attractor with *unique* SRB measure** | single full-volume basin | for *almost every* \(x_0\) the time average of \(g\) converges to the same constant \(\int g\,d\mu_{\text{SRB}}\) | for *any* absolutely-continuous \(\mu_0\) the Cesàro average of measures converges to \(\mu_{\text{SRB}}\) – no dependence left |
| **Integrable Hamiltonian system with invariant tori** | each torus is its own basin but Lebesgue measure of each torus is 0 | orbit from \(x_0\) stays on its torus; time average depends on that torus | an a.c. \(\mu_0\) spreads mass over many tori ⇒ Cesàro averages don’t converge to a single probability: different subsequences pick different convex combinations |

**Bottom line**

* If the dynamics provides **one physical/SRB measure and only one**, then any reasonable initial choice (point or density) is funneled to that same statistical law, so the long-time averages are independent of the start.

* If there are **several physical measures**—because the attractor splits into distinct basins—then both single-orbit and distributional averages **do** depend on where your initial state (or the mass of your density) sits.

What you “need extra’’ beyond the bare notion of an attractor is *exactly* that **uniqueness of the physical measure** (often established via hyperbolicity, a spectral gap of the transfer operator, etc.) to eliminate that dependence.
Oh well, I'm not too worried about that. I just care whether it converges to a value at all. Does that matter?

thoughts.content: OK, the user seems focused on whether convergence happens to a value, not about the specifics of initial conditions or uniqueness. Their question is about whether this convergence relies on uniqueness or physical measure. They're asking about the existence of a limit for the entire trajectory, with no need for subsequences or expectations of average measures. It sounds like they just care if a limit exists and don’t need to dive into deeper mathematical properties.

For Cesàro average convergence, uniqueness isn't strictly necessary, but we need conditions that ensure the sequence does converge. If there are multiple limit points, convergence may fail. To guarantee convergence to a specific limit, we need to ensure the initial measure lies within the basin of a unique invariant measure, and that this measure is ergodic. Without these conditions, convergence might happen, but not to a specific value. So, yes, it matters if we don’t guarantee uniqueness, but there are still ways for convergence to occur.

The system might have convergence for time averages, especially when periodic, or with two attractors. However, for systems like rotations by irrational numbers, Cesàro averages converge but the orbit time average may need more nuanced tools like Birkhoff. For systems involving multiple tori, convergence depends on mixing or uniqueness, such as when attractor sets have a single invariant measure. In general, Cesàro averages can converge, but only with conditions like mixing across invariant measures—otherwise, convergence may fail. Still, weak convergence can occur under certain scenarios.

To guarantee convergence of time averages for any given measure, the Cesàro averages must converge. This often requires the initial distribution's decomposing into ergodic components that involve invariant measures. Even if these components aren't uniquely ergodic, the Cesàro average might still converge to a mixture as long as the initial measure maintains consistency within those components. However, in pathological cases like systems lacking proper mixing or invariant measures, convergence could fail—though such cases are rare.

parts:
It only matters **to the extent that you want a limit that is
*always* the same, no matter how you start**.  
For mere *existence* of a limit you do **not** need uniqueness of the
physical/SRB measure—-but you still need just enough structure so that
the particular initial condition (a point or a density) you picked
lands, asymptotically, inside a single “ergodic block.’’

---

## 1 How a limit can exist without uniqueness

Any probability measure \(\mu\) on a compact forward–invariant set
admits a unique **ergodic decomposition**

\[
\mu \;=\;\int_{\mathcal E} \!\nu\;d\lambda(\nu),
\quad
\text{each }\nu\text{ ergodic and invariant.}
\]

During the evolution

\[
\mu_t=\Phi^{t}_{\#}\mu
\quad\Longrightarrow\quad
\bar\mu_T=\frac1T\int_{0}^{T}\!\mu_t\,dt
\]

the weights \(\lambda\) stay unchanged; inside every ergodic component
the time–average smears out to \(\nu\) itself (Birkhoff on that
component).  Hence

\[
\bar\mu_T\;\xrightarrow{w^{*}}\;
\underbrace{\int_{\mathcal E}\!\nu\,d\lambda(\nu)}_{=\;\mu\_{\text{erg}}},
\]

and for every bounded observable \(g\)

\[
\frac1T\int_{0}^{T}\!\int g\,d\mu_t\,dt
\;\longrightarrow\;
\int g\,d\mu_{\text{erg}} .
\]

So **convergence is automatic** provided

* the phase space is compact (or mass cannot escape), and
* your *initial* measure does not split its mass between ergodic
  components whose internal Birkhoff averages fail to settle
  (this pathological situation cannot occur for continuous flows on
  compact spaces).

---

## 2 When convergence can *fail*

It can break only if at least one of the following happens

| obstacle | what goes wrong |
|----------|-----------------|
| **Escape of mass** | Probability leaks to infinity ⇒ no tightness, no subsequence limit. |
| **Initial condition straddles two basins whose averages oscillate** | Possible for discontinuous maps or non-compact spaces: the Cesàro average can jump back and forth, giving different subsequence limits. |
| **Observable not integrable on the limiting measure** | If \(g\notin L^{1}(\nu)\) on some ergodic component, the time average of \(g\) may diverge even though the measure average exists for bounded observables. |

For the classical setting you have in mind—continuous flow, compact
attractor—none of those obstacles occurs.

---

## 3 Why people nevertheless insist on a
**unique physical measure**

* **Robust predictability** – the long-time statistics are the
  *same* for *every* absolutely-continuous initial state; you never
  have to ask which basin you started in.
* **Fast convergence** – uniqueness in hyperbolic or Lasota–Yorke
  settings usually comes with a spectral gap, giving exponential decay
  of transients rather than merely Cesàro convergence.
* **Cleaner theory** – uniqueness lets you drop the words “for
  \(\lambda\)-a.e. component’’ from limit statements.

---

### Take-away

*To get a limit at all* you only need that the trajectory or density
is eventually trapped in one ergodic component—something already true
for flows on a compact attractor.

*To get a limit that is **independent** of how you start (and that
often appears with an exponential rate)* you need, in addition, that
there be **one** physical/SRB measure for the whole basin of the
attractor.

If you “just care whether it converges’’ for your particular initial
state, the weaker compact-plus-invariance hypothesis is already
enough; uniqueness simply upgrades “sometimes converges’’ to
“always converges to the same law.’’

parts:
A concise way to write the “non-unique but convergent’’ case is to let the **limit measure keep an explicit tag that reminds you it depends on the starting density**.  One common notation is \(\mu_{(\rho_0)}\):

\[
\boxed{\;
\lim_{t\to\infty}\;\int_{\mathbb{R}^{n}}\!
        \phi(x)\,\rho(x,t)\,dx
      \;=\;
      \int_{\mathbb{R}^{n}}\!\phi(x)\;d\mu_{(\rho_0)}(x)
\;}\tag{5}
\]

* **\(\rho(x,t)\,dx\)** is the push-forward of the *chosen* initial density \(\rho_0\,dx\).
* **\(\displaystyle\mu_{(\rho_0)}\)** is **an invariant probability measure** that emerges as the weak limit of \(\rho(\,\cdot\,,t)\,dx\).  
  - If the dynamics admits several invariant measures, \(\mu_{(\rho_0)}\) records **which basin of attraction** the initial mass \(\rho_0\) fell into.  
  - Should two different initial densities land in different basins, their limits—and hence the right-hand side—may differ.

> *If you need to emphasise that only subsequences are guaranteed to converge*, you can write  
> \[
> \lim_{k\to\infty}\int\phi\,d\mu_{t_k}
> \;=\;
> \int\phi\,d\mu_\*(x),
> \quad
> \mu_\*\in\mathcal I,
> \]
> where \(\mathcal I\) is the (possibly non-single-ton) set of invariant measures.

But when the full sequence \(\rho(\,\cdot\,,t)\) is known to converge (even though different \(\rho_0\) may pick different limits), Equation (5) captures the situation succinctly.
Yes or no, if you know that you have a global attractor, this is sufficient to say that the expectation of a smooth bounded function \phi  at a time t, as t goes to infinity, converges.

thoughts.content: To answer yes or no, we need to think about how a global attractor works. While it draws trajectories towards itself, it doesn't necessarily ensure uniqueness or convergence of expectations for all starting points. For example, imagine a system with multiple stable cycles; the expectation could vary based on the starting point. A chaotic system might also have a recurrent orbit without expected convergence, even though the observable could be bounded. If the question involves initial distributions, that's another important factor to consider.

When there's no specified initial distribution, the expectation of a smooth function at time t might involve integrating over the phase space using a density function. With a global attractor, the push-forward measure might still struggle to converge over time, especially if there are split cycles. In chaotic systems, like irrational rotations or the Feigenbaum attractor, densities may not converge due to mixing properties. However, for mixing systems, it seems that expectations often could converge as the density becomes uniform on cycles. Ultimately, the convergence depends on the system's specific dynamics.

parts:
**No.**

A global attractor guarantees that every bounded orbit is eventually *trapped* in a fixed compact-invariant set, but it does **not** guarantee that the distribution of mass on that set stops moving.  
If, once on the attractor,

* the flow merely **permutes** points (e.g. rigid rotation along an attracting circle), or  
* different parts of the initial density fall into basins of several invariant components (two disjoint stable limit cycles, a Cantor–like Feigenbaum set, …),

then \(\rho(\,\cdot\,,t)\) can keep sliding around and the integral  
\(\displaystyle\int \phi\,\rho(\,\cdot\,,t)\,dx\) can keep oscillating instead of converging.  
Extra structure—typically a *unique physical/SRB measure* or some mixing/spectral-gap condition—is needed to make those expectations settle to a single limit.

Okay, in that case, if you have a unique physical measure yes or no, does the limit of the expectation value exist? And second, if I reduce the restrictions such that I only care if the time average exists, doesn't attract or guarantee that.

thoughts.content:
For the first question: Yes, expectations will converge for any absolutely continuous (a.c.) initial distribution to a unique physical measure, though mixing may be needed in some cases.

For the second question: Yes, if you reduce the conditions to focus on the time average, the attractor will ensure that the time average exists. However, instantaneous expectations may still not converge without mixing.

parts:
**First question – unique physical measure**

* **Yes.**  
  If the flow (or map) has **one and only one physical/SRB measure \(\mu_{\text{phys}}\)**, then for any absolutely-continuous initial density \(\rho_0\,dx\)

  \[
    \int_{\mathbb R^{n}}\phi(x)\,\rho(x,t)\,dx
    \;\xrightarrow{t\to\infty}\;
    \int_{\mathbb R^{n}}\phi(x)\,d\mu_{\text{phys}}(x)
    \qquad\text{for every bounded-continuous }\phi .
  \]

  The uniqueness plus “physical’’ (positive-volume basin) property forces the push-forward measures \(\mu_t=\Phi^{t}_{\#}\rho_0\,dx\) themselves to converge weak-\(*\) to \(\mu_{\text{phys}}\); the expectations therefore converge as well.  No time–averaging is needed.

---

**Second question – only care about the time-average**

* **Yes – a global attractor is already enough for the Cesàro (time-averaged) limit.**  
  With a compact global attractor \(\mathcal A\) the family of push-forward measures is tight, so the Cesàro averages  

  \[
      \bar\mu_T=\frac1T\int_{0}^{T}\mu_t\,dt
  \]

  always have weak-\(*\) limit points; hence for any bounded-continuous \(\phi\)

  \[
    \frac1T\int_{0}^{T}\!
      \int_{\mathbb R^{n}}\!\phi(x)\,\rho(x,t)\,dx\,dt
    \;\longrightarrow\;
    \int_{\mathbb R^{n}}\phi(x)\,d\mu_\*(x)
  \]

  for **some** invariant probability measure \(\mu_\*\) supported on \(\mathcal A\).  
  The attractor does **not** choose *which* invariant measure when several exist, but it **does** guarantee that the time-averaged expectation converges.

thoughts.content:
It looks like the user is asking for functional requirements regarding attractors, and I need to clarify the meaning of "tractor" as "attractor." I'll provide conditions related to different tiers:

- Tier 0: Compact forward invariant + continuity — Cesàro subsequences converge for initial measures supported in set.
- Tier 1: Global attractor (compact, invariant, attracting) — Cesàro averages converge for any bounded initial distribution, though the limit depends on the initial distribution.
- Tier 2: Ergodic invariant measure — Orbit time averages converge almost everywhere, with the flow transitive within support.
- Tier 3: Physical measures — Existence of hyperbolicity and uniform expansion for invariant measures with positive Lebesgue basin.
